I think that Catholics have always taken the story of the Fall literally enough to be history but figuratively enough to be allegory. I think it could be an entirely literal account. But I do not discount that it could be a figurative story steeped in essential, non-negotiable truths. It is like the other Christian mysteries that we know much about but not everything. There are two points of the story that must be taken as certainties: the fall was a fall and the infusion of a soul by God was not an evolution (even if there was an evolution of the body).
 
 One who cannot understand the truths of the Creation and Fall story of Eden cannot understand the truths of the Incarnation, Crucifixion, and Resurrection of the Gospels. The parallels between the two are striking. The Church Fathers wrote about this. Jesus is the new and perfected Adam. Mary is the new and perfected Eve. 
 
 The disobedience of the woman of Eve was undone by the obedience of the woman Mary (St. Irenaeus).
 
 Eve brought death into the world as Mary brought life into the world (St. Jerome).
 
 Eve was the mother of all mankind as Mary is the Mother of the Church. 
 
 In the Garden of Eden, man was created in the image of God. In the Incarnation, God's image actually became man. 
 
 The Fall of Man took place in a garden just as the Redemption of Man did at the crucifixion/resurrection. (John Chapter 19) 
 
 In the Garden of Eden, death was instituted at the Tree of Life. At the Crucifixion, life was restored on a tree of death. 
 
 Adam was the word for "man." Jesus often referred to himself as the "Son of Man." Sin and death came into the world through one man and grace/everlasting life came into the world through one man. (Romans 5:12, 17)
 
 God breathed life into Adam. A resurrected Jesus breathed the eternal life of the Holy Spirit into the apostles. (John 20)
 
 As I wrote earlier, from the viewpoint of the Christian, the Fall  must be a fall. It must be a fall from a higher state, one that was closer to divinity. If, in Christianity, God is a perfect being, the standard of justice, then his creations would have been perfect. The actions of his creations would have been sinless. The union of God and man would have been totally upright and moral. It is very evident that this relationship has been damaged. It is a fact that "sin" exists. The wrench in the system was free will. 
 
 As Chesterton wrote it, "Certain new theologians dispute original sin, which is the only part of Christian theology which can really be proved."* "The first fact is the fact that original sin is really original. Not merely in theology but in history it is a thing rooted in the origins. Whatever else men have believed, they have all believed that there is something the matter with mankind. This sense of sin has made it impossible to be natural and have no clothes, just as it has made it impossible to be natural and have no laws."** 
 
 But it is not outside of the capability of God to have worked through evolution. "God could have infused a soul into an already existing being, having previously prepared a body to suit it, making it a 'man'."*** 
 
 Advances in the sciences "lead one no longer to regard the theory of evolution as a mere hypothesis."**** But there are many theories of evolution. Some are contrary to the Christian faith. "The theories of evolution which, in line with the philosophies which inspire them, regard the spirit as something that emerges from the forces of living matter or as a mere epiphenomenon of that matter, are incompatible with the truth about man"**** To paraphrase with Chesterton's words, "Nature is not our mother, she is our sister." 
 
 Although a possibility or probability, evolution is not a thorough explanation of the Christian view of man. The mind and soul of man are fatal flaws of a completely evolutionary theory. Free will is another breaking point because there is only fate or natural selection or randomness in evolution. Evolution is not even a full explanation of the scientific view of man. "... evolution really is mistaken for explanation. It has the fatal quality of leaving on many minds the impression that they do understand it and everything else; just as many of them live under a sort of illusion that they have read the Origin of Species. But this notion of something smooth and slow, like the ascent of a slope, is a great part of the illusion. It is an illogicality as well as an illusion; for slowness has really nothing to do with the question. An event is not any more intrinsically intelligible or unintelligible because of the pace at which it moves. For a man who does not believe in a miracle, a slow miracle would be just as incredible as a swift one."**
 
 "The sincerity of Darwin really admitted this; and that is how we came to use such a term as the Missing Link. But the dogmatism of Darwinians has been too strong for the agnosticism of Darwin; and men have insensibly fallen into turning this entirely negative term into a positive image. They talk of searching for the habits and habitat of the Missing Link; as if one were to talk of being on friendly terms with the gap in a narrative or the hole in an argument, of taking a walk with a non-sequitir or dining with an undistributed middle...I shall waste no further space on these speculations on the nature of man before he became man. His body may have been evolved from the brutes; but we know nothing of any such transition that throws the smallest light upon his soul as it has shown itself in history."**
 
 "There may be a broken trail of stones and bones faintly suggesting the development of the human body. There is nothing even faintly suggesting such a development of the human mind. It was not and it was; we know not in what instant or infinity of years. Something happened; and it has all the appearance of a transaction outside time."**
 
 "Whether or no the garden was an allegory, the truth itself can be very well allegorized as a garden. And the point of it is that Man, whatever else he is, is certainly not merely one of the plants of the garden that has plucked its roots out of the soil and walked about with them like legs...He is something else, something strange and solitary."***** 
 
 *Orthodoxy G.K. Chesterton

 ***The Pentateuch Navarre Study Bible
 ****Pope John Paul II message to the Pontifical Academy of Sciences October 1996
 *****The Thing  G.K. Chesterton
